reportSummary.summary: The Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek Watershed Plan details a comprehensive strategy to address nutrient, sediment, and pathogen impairments through the implementation of BMPs, targeted outreach, and ongoing monitoring. Covering 35,085 acres in Tate County, Mississippi, this plan sets reduction goals for organic enrichment, nutrients, and fecal coliform, coordinates federal and state partners, and provides a timeline and measurable benchmarks to guide water quality restoration efforts.
reportSummary.planTitle: Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek Watershed Plan GY 2017
organizations: Mississippi Soil and Water Conservation Commission
Tate County Soil and Water Conservation District

goals.description: Achieve the modeled nonpoint source (NPS) loads in the TMDL for nutrients by implementing conservation practices that target both TN, TP, and sediment reduction.
goals.schedule: During the project implementation period, through BMP installation.
goals.sourceExcerpt: In order to achieve the modeled NPS loads in the TMDL, nutrient BMPs will be implemented watershed. This will be done by implementing in-field conservation practices that target both TN, TP and sediment reduction as soils in MS are known to have high phosphorus content.

goals.description: Reduce fecal coliform loading by 50% in Hickahala Creek and by 70% in James Wolf Creek within the watershed.
goals.schedule: During the project implementation period, in accordance with the 2003 TMDL.
goals.sourceExcerpt: The Fecal Coliform TMDL for Hickahala Creek is calling for a 50% reduction in the section of Hickahala Creek that is located within the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek Watershed. The same TMDL also calls for a 70% reduction in James Wolf Creek.

bmps.name: Fencing
bmps.description: Install fencing in pasturelands and lands used for grazing to limit livestock access to streams.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: installation of the following BMPs would mitigate sediment and nutrient issues in the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek watershed helping the stream recover: fencing, watering facilities, heavy use areas, ponds, streambank and shoreline protection, and grade stabilization structures.

bmps.name: Tank/Trough (Watering Facilities)
bmps.description: Install watering facilities to provide livestock with alternative water sources away from streams.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: installation of the following BMPs would mitigate sediment and nutrient issues in the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek watershed helping the stream recover: fencing, watering facilities, heavy use areas, ponds, streambank and shoreline protection, and grade stabilization structures.

bmps.name: Ponds
bmps.description: Construct farm ponds for water management and to reduce runoff pollution.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: installation of the following BMPs would mitigate sediment and nutrient issues in the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek watershed helping the stream recover: fencing, watering facilities, heavy use areas, ponds, streambank and shoreline protection, and grade stabilization structures.

bmps.name: Streambank and Shoreline Protection
bmps.description: Stabilize streambanks and shorelines to reduce erosion and sediment/nutrient runoff.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: installation of the following BMPs would mitigate sediment and nutrient issues in the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek watershed helping the stream recover: fencing, watering facilities, heavy use areas, ponds, streambank and shoreline protection, and grade stabilization structures.

bmps.name: Grade Stabilization Structure
bmps.description: Install grade stabilization structures to control gully erosion and manage water flow.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: installation of the following BMPs would mitigate sediment and nutrient issues in the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek watershed helping the stream recover: fencing, watering facilities, heavy use areas, ponds, streambank and shoreline protection, and grade stabilization structures.

bmps.name: Heavy Use Area Protection
bmps.description: Install protection measures in heavy use areas to prevent soil erosion and water contamination.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: installation of the following BMPs would mitigate sediment and nutrient issues in the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek watershed helping the stream recover: fencing, watering facilities, heavy use areas, ponds, streambank and shoreline protection, and grade stabilization structures.

implementation.description: Develop, execute, and implement a Subgrant Agreement that specifies roles, tasks, requirements, and milestones for project implementation.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Work to develop, execute, and implement a Subgrant Agreement that specifies the roles, tasks, requirements, and milestones for project implementation. (Month 1)

implementation.description: Facilitate meetings, media and social media promotion of the project, and coordinate activities to fully implement the plan.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Facilitate, in coordination with MDEQ and other partners, meetings, media and social media promotion of the project, and coordinate activities to fully implement this plan. (Months 1-36)

implementation.description: Inform landowners and operators about the project and work to secure commitments from priority area landowners and operators who are willing to participate.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Work with the Tate County SWCD, MSWCC, NRCS, and MDEQ to inform landowners and operators within the watershed about the project and work to secure commitments from priority area landowners and operators who are willing to participate in the project. (Months 1-6)

implementation.description: Determine, through GIS applications and site surveys, the priority areas within the sub-watershed contributing significant pollutant loads, and install BMPs following NRCS Technical Field Manual guidelines.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Work with the local SWCD, MSWCC, NRCS, and MDEQ to determine through GIS applications and intensive site surveys the priority areas within the sub-watershed that are contributing significant pollutant loads. All BMPs shall be installed in accordance with the guidelines developed in the latest edition of the NRCS Technical Field Manual...

implementation.description: Implement a plan to monitor baseline water quality conditions in the watershed and track changes over time resulting from the BMPs implemented.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Facilitate, in cooperation with MDEQ and other monitoring partners, the completion and implementation of an effective and efficient plan to monitor baseline water quality conditions in the watershed and track changes in water quality over time resulting from the BMPs implemented through this project. (Plan Completion: Months 1-2); Implementation: Months 3-36)

implementation.description: Submit blank copies of standard maintenance agreements to MDEQ.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Submit blank copies of standard maintenance agreements to MDEQ. (Months 13-36)

implementation.description: Conduct inspections of BMPs during construction.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Conduct inspections of BMPs during construction (Months 3-36)

implementation.description: Coordinate with and support local partners in the collection of GPS coordinates of all installed BMPs and incorporate into a GIS format.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Coordinate with and support the local SWCD, MACD, MSWCC and NRCS in the collection of relevant GPS coordinates of all installed BMPs and incorporate this information into a GIS format. All geospatial data shall be collected in a manner consistent with the Federal Geographic Data committee-endorsed standards. (Months 3-36)

implementation.description: Collect adequate photo documentation before, during, and after installation of the approved BMPs.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Collect adequate photo documentation before, during, and after installation of the approved BMPs (Months 3-36)

implementation.description: Report measured, or estimated, nonpoint source pollutant load reduction, acreage affected, pre-and post- site conditions, and GIS data.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Report measured, or estimated, nonpoint source pollutant load reduction, acreage affected, pre-and post- site conditions, and GIS data (1-36)

monitoring.method: water quality sampling and in-situ field measurement
monitoring.frequency: as determined by project monitoring plan

thresholds.description: Daily Average of 5.0 mg/L; Instantaneous threshold of 4.0 mg/L

monitoring.sourceExcerpt: the water quality standard for dissolved oxygen is a daily average of 5.0 mg/L with an instantaneous minimum of 4.0 mg/L

monitoring.frequency: as determined by project monitoring plan
as determined by project monitoring plan
as determined by project monitoring plan
as determined by project monitoring plan

thresholds.description: Monthly average less than 750 mg/L; instantaneous threshold less than 1500 mg/L

monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Dissolved Solids Monthly average less than 750 mg/L; instantaneous threshold less than 1500 mg/L

monitoring.frequency: as determined by project monitoring plan
as determined by project monitoring plan

thresholds.description: 0.940-1.110 mg/L (threshold range based on healthy biologically attaining streams in West Bioregion)

monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Total Nitrogen 0.940-1.110 mg/L (threshold range based on healthy biologically attaining streams in West Bioregion)

monitoring.frequency: as determined by project monitoring plan

thresholds.description: 0.080-0.120 mg/L (threshold range based on healthy biologically attaining streams in West Bioregion)

monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Total Phosphorus 0.080-0.120 mg/L (threshold range based on healthy biologically attaining streams in West Bioregion)

monitoring.frequency: 30-day geometric mean and individual samples during 30-day period

thresholds.description: 30-day geometric mean of 126 per 100 ml; samples during 30-day period should not exceed 410 per 100 ml more than 10% of the time

monitoring.sourceExcerpt: E. coli 30-day geometric mean of 126 per 100 ml; samples during 30-day period should not exceed 410 per 100 ml more than 10% of the time

outreach.description: Diversified information/education programs, best management practices manuals, literature, books, videos, and public service announcements addressing pollutants from seven major landuse categories of Nonpoint Source Pollution.
outreach.schedule: Ongoing, with materials used throughout project duration as tailored for the watershed.
outreach.indicator: Participation rates, distribution of materials, evaluation forms, pre/post-tests, surveys.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: The MDEQ, in cooperation with numerous federal, state, and local stakeholders has developed diversified information/education programs, best management practices manuals, literature, books, videos, and public service announcements that address pollutants from the seven (7) major landuse categories of Nonpoint Source Pollution...

outreach.description: Teacher Workshops and Train the Trainer workshops for Soil and Water districts, Extension Service, etc.
outreach.schedule: As needed in proximity to the watershed and for target audiences.
outreach.indicator: Number of educators and trainers trained, workshop attendance.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Teacher Workshops – train educators in proximity to the watershed about NPS pollution and provide materials and information that can be used in their classrooms... 'Train the Trainer' – workshops and materials for Soil and Water districts, Extension Service, etc.

outreach.description: Watershed Implementation Team (WIT) meetings for updates on implementation activities, education events, and plan review/modification (minimum of 3 face-to-face meetings).
outreach.schedule: At least 3 meetings during the project period; scheduled as part of implementation and outreach.
outreach.indicator: Number of meetings held, participant attendance, stakeholder engagement.
partners: Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek Watershed Implementation Team (WIT)
outreach.sourceExcerpt: the stakeholder group forming the Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek Watershed Implementation Team (WIT) will participate in a minimum of 3 face-to-face meetings. The purpose of these meetings is to provide updates on implementation activities, education events and review and modify the watershed plan.

outreach.description: Field days to showcase the implemented BMPs for the public.
outreach.schedule: During project period as part of outreach and plan updates.
outreach.indicator: Number of field days held, participant feedback.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: The purpose of the meetings will be for updating the watershed plan, and hosting field days to showcase the implemented BMPs for the public.

geographicAreas.sourceExcerpt: The Basket Creek-Hickahala Creek watershed is located in Tate County and covers 35,085 acres.
